spanishExample: ¡Fueron *rude* conmigo ese día y eso no se hace!
englishTranslation: They were rude with me that day and that isn’t done!
vocabIncluded: hacerse: any use of Hacer with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become"

spanishExample: ¿Quién *knows* lo que hago?
englishTranslation: Who knows what I’m doing?
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases

spanishExample: Ellos *would know* si ella fuera.
englishTranslation: They would know if she went.

spanishExample: Esto no se tiene que hacer para nada.
englishTranslation: This doesn’t have to be done at all.
vocabIncluded: hacerse: any use of Hacer with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become"
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Fui un buen *citizen* porque *I voted.*
englishTranslation: I was a good citizen(m) because I voted.

spanishExample: Hace un nuevo *program.*
englishTranslation: She is making a new program(m).

spanishExample: Hacemos lo que no se ha hecho.
englishTranslation: We do what hasn’t been done.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
hacerse: any use of Hacer with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become"

spanishExample: Hacen su *job.*
englishTranslation: They are doing their job.

spanishExample: Hay *cars* de más que *can* ir hasta *the next city.*
englishTranslation: There are extra cars that can go until the next city.
vocabIncluded: hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)

spanishExample: *I hoped* que no tuviera *any trouble.*
englishTranslation: I hoped she didn’t have any trouble.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Lo tuve todo y fue un *mistake.*
englishTranslation: (preterite) I had it all and it was a mistake.
vocabIncluded: lo + Tener + todo: "to have it all" (idiom)

spanishExample: Me hago tu amigo.
englishTranslation: I’m becoming your friend.
vocabIncluded: hacerse: any use of Hacer with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become"

spanishExample: Mi *mom hoped* que yo tuviera más *money.*
englishTranslation: My mom hoped I had more money.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: No está de más *to remind you* que tú fuiste *the problem* ese día.
englishTranslation: It couldn’t hurt to remind you that you were the problem that day.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
no está de más: "it couldn't hurt" (idiom)

spanishExample: No hacemos todo lo que haces.
englishTranslation: We aren’t doing everything that you do.

spanishExample: No lo haces, así que ella lo hace.
englishTranslation: You don’t do it, so she does it.

spanishExample: Se hacen buenos *students.*
englishTranslation: They’re becoming good students.
vocabIncluded: hacerse: any use of Hacer with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become"

spanishExample: *Several projects* se han hecho.
englishTranslation: Several projects have been done.
vocabIncluded: hacerse: any use of Hacer with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become"
han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Si ella estuviera por ahí, tendría de todo.
englishTranslation: If she were around, it would have a bit of everything.
vocabIncluded: tendría: "would have", "he/she/it would have" (Tener, conditional, 3rd person)
tiene de todo: "has some of everything" (idiom)

spanishExample: Si estuviera por ahí, *I would eat* sí o sí.
englishTranslation: If I were around, I would eat no matter what.

spanishExample: Si fuera *an artist* en vez de *a scientist, I could create* más.
englishTranslation: If I were an artist instead of a scientist, I could create more.

spanishExample: Si fuera *different, I would call* a mi amigo.
englishTranslation: If I were different, I would call my friend.
vocabIncluded: "the personal a": using an extra "a" before a direct object when it's a person

spanishExample: También nos hacemos *a family.*
englishTranslation: We are also becoming a family.
vocabIncluded: hacerse: any use of Hacer with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become"

spanishExample: Te haces un *great professional.*
englishTranslation: You’re becoming a great professional.
vocabIncluded: hacerse: any use of Hacer with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become"

spanishExample: *They hoped* que no fuera ni *to the hospital* ni *to the clinic.*
englishTranslation: They hoped I didn’t go either to the hospital or to the clinic.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Todas las cosas se tienen que hacer ahora.
englishTranslation: All the things have to be done now.
vocabIncluded: hacerse: any use of Hacer with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become"
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Todos fuimos buenos esa vez, hasta tu amigo.
englishTranslation: We all were good that time, even your friend(m).

spanishExample: Yo lo hago, pero ellos no lo hacen.
englishTranslation: I do it, but they don’t do it.
